Award.AwardTitle: Surface Reaction Pathways on Model Gold Palladium Alloy Catalysts
Award.AbstractNarration: The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation will support the research program of Professor Wilfred Tysoe of the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. Dr. Tysoe and his students will explore oxidative reaction pathways on model gold-palladium alloy catalysts, using a combination of surface science spectroscopic probes and computational modeling of the reaction processes. The work focuses on developing a molecular level understanding of reaction pathways for vinyl acetate monomer synthesis, direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis, and CO and alcohol oxidation reactions. The nature of the surface oxygen displaying catalytic activity will be probed in these studies. Fundamental insights obtained in these studies will aid in the design and development of active catalysts for commercial application. The work also provides a training ground for students in this technologically important field. Women and underrepresented minority students make up a large portion of the research team.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

Many transition metals act as catalysts. That is, they accelerate the rate of a chemical reaction without undergoing a permanent change, and the use of such catalysts underpins a large fraction of the US economy. The properties of metal catalysts can often be improved by mixing two metals to form an alloy. One class of such alloys combines an active (for example, palladium) and less-active metal (gold). Gold-palladium alloys are extensively used to synthesize vinyl acetate monomer (VAM) from a reaction between ethylene, acetic acid and oxygen, which is used to make paints and adhesives. The goal of this project is to understand the reaction pathway for VAM formation and the effects that control it. Since catalytic reactions occur on the surface, experiments are carried out in the absence of air, which would contaminate the surface, under so-called ultrahigh vacuum conditions. Reactions are studied on clean, single-crystalline model catalysts, where the number and distribution of the gold and palladium atoms on the surface are known. It has been shown by others that such simple model catalysts reproduce the activity of more-complex commercial catalysts very well. The reaction mechanism is studied using an array of surface-sensitive analytic techniques, combined with theoretical (quantum mechanics) calculations to aid in the interpretation of the data. We find that VAM is formed by the same reaction pathway on all model metal and alloy catalysts that we studied, by the so-called Samanos mechanism. Here, acetic acid (the basis of vinegar) reacts with the surface of the catalyst by losing a hydrogen atom to form adsorbed acetate species. Ethylene (C2H4) then couples to the acetate species to form a short-lived intermediate that then loses a second hydrogen to form VAM. The hydrogen reacts with oxygen to produce water.

We also investigated the effect of alloy structure on the catalytic activity and found that alloying palladium with gold produces a more active VAM formation catalyst, as found commercially. The catalytic activity of alloys is conventionally described using two effects; “electronic” and “ensemble” effects. As “electronic” effect implies, the activity is proposed to improve by one metal in the alloy (here, gold) modifying the electronic structure of the second metal (palladium) to influence its reactivity. In the “ensemble effect”, a particular arrangement of atoms at the surface influences the ability of adsorbates to bind to the alloy. While we did identify both of these effects in our experiments, we also discovered a third effect; the influence of the decrease in the number of molecules that could adsorb on the surface (called the adsorbate coverage) as the concentration of the active metal (palladium) decreased. This occurs because adsorbed molecules tend to repel each other as they become closer, so that the energy increases as the coverage increases. Thus, if a surface reaction occurs in which bonds are broken, thereby increasing the coverage, the reaction becomes less favorable at high coverages. Conversely, if a reaction occurs by forming bonds, so that the surface coverage decreases, the reaction becomes more favorable at high coverages. Since the Samanos mechanism described above has a sequence of two reaction steps; the first, coupling step forms a bond, while the second step, in which a hydrogen atom is lost, breaks a bond. Thus, lowering the coverage by decreasing the concentration of palladium on the surfaces facilitates reactions in which bonds are broken and, in the case of VAM formation, leads to an overall increase in catalytic activity.

Curiously, we also found that the alloys with large amounts of gold (more than 50%) on the surface, which had been found to be the most active for VAM formation at high pressures, were completely ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Overview Many transition metals act as catalysts. That is, they accelerate the rate of a chemical reaction without undergoing a permanent change, and the use of such catalysts underpins a large fraction of the US economy. The properties of metal catalysts can often be improved by mixing two metals to form an alloy. One class of such alloys combines an active (for example, palladium) and less-active metal (gold). Gold-palladium alloys are extensively used to synthesize vinyl acetate monomer (VAM) from a reaction between ethylene, acetic acid and oxygen, which is used to make paints and adhesives. The goal of this project is to understand the reaction pathway for VAM formation and the effects that control it. Since catalytic reactions occur on the surface, experiments are carried out in the absence of air, which would contaminate the surface, under so-called ultrahigh vacuum conditions. Reactions are studied on clean, single-crystalline model catalysts, where the number and distribution of the gold and palladium atoms on the surface are known. It has been shown by others that such simple model catalysts reproduce the activity of more-complex commercial catalysts very well. The reaction mechanism is studied using an array of surface-sensitive analytic techniques, combined with theoretical (quantum mechanics) calculations to aid in the interpretation of the data. We find that VAM is formed by the same reaction pathway on all model metal and alloy catalysts that we studied, by the so-called Samanos mechanism. Here, acetic acid (the basis of vinegar) reacts with the surface of the catalyst by losing a hydrogen atom to form adsorbed acetate species. Ethylene (C2H4) then couples to the acetate species to form a short-lived intermediate that then loses a second hydrogen to form VAM. The hydrogen reacts with oxygen to produce water. We also investigated the effect of alloy structure on the catalytic activity and found that alloying palladium with gold produces a more active VAM formation catalyst, as found commercially. The catalytic activity of alloys is conventionally described using two effects; "electronic" and "ensemble" effects. As "electronic" effect implies, the activity is proposed to improve by one metal in the alloy (here, gold) modifying the electronic structure of the second metal (palladium) to influence its reactivity. In the "ensemble effect", a particular arrangement of atoms at the surface influences the ability of adsorbates to bind to the alloy. While we did identify both of these effects in our experiments, we also discovered a third effect; the influence of the decrease in the number of molecules that could adsorb on the surface (called the adsorbate coverage) as the concentration of the active metal (palladium) decreased. This occurs because adsorbed molecules tend to repel each other as they become closer, so that the energy increases as the coverage increases. Thus, if a surface reaction occurs in which bonds are broken, thereby increasing the coverage, the reaction becomes less favorable at high coverages. Conversely, if a reaction occurs by forming bonds, so that the surface coverage decreases, the reaction becomes more favorable at high coverages. Since the Samanos mechanism described above has a sequence of two reaction steps; the first, coupling step forms a bond, while the second step, in which a hydrogen atom is lost, breaks a bond. Thus, lowering the coverage by decreasing the concentration of palladium on the surfaces facilitates reactions in which bonds are broken and, in the case of VAM formation, leads to an overall increase in catalytic activity. Curiously, we also found that the alloys with large amounts of gold (more than 50%) on the surface, which had been found to be the most active for VAM formation at high pressures, were completely inactive under our ultrahigh vacuum conditions.
